The CO2 cycloaddition with ethylene oxide (EO) to generate ethylene carbonate (EC) is a green method for converting exhaust gas into fine chemicals. However, pure MgO exhibits low EC yield under halogen-free and mild reaction conditions. This study explores EC generation on single-atom catalysts of MgO(100) surfaces loaded with Cu, Ag, Au, Zn, Na, K, Ca, Sr, Ba, Al, Ga and In through density functional theory (DFT) calculation. The results show that the mechanism reversal observed in the reaction pathway for EC generation and the role of CO₂ are attributed to changes in the electrons number obtained by EO and CO₂ co-adsorbed on the MgO(100) surfaces loaded with metals. For EC generation, surfaces loaded with Cu, Ag, Au, and Zn show a synergistic route where EO and CO₂ obtained fewer than 0.50 |e|. However, other surfaces have a stepwise pathway when this number exceeds 0.50. The participation of CO₂'s frontier orbitals in the reaction depends on the electrons obtained from the catalyst. On the Cu, Ag, Au, Zn, Na, and K-MgO(100) surfaces, CO₂ obtains fewer than 0.50 |e| and contributes LUMO orbitals, whereas on other surfaces, it obtains >0.50 |e| and contributes HOMO orbitals. Notably, the Cu-MgO(100) surface exhibits over 98 % EC selectivity at 1 atm and 298 K due to its weak alkalinity. It provides an ideal microenvironment that activates EO and CO2, replacing the role of halogens and offering a novel catalyst to significantly boost EC yield under halogen-free and mild reaction conditions. In this regard, ethylene carbonate (EC) is an important raw material for polycarbonate synthesis [3]. The cycloaddition of epoxides with CO2 to generate EC is notable for its 100% atomic utilization and its efficient conversion of CO2 into fine chemicals [3–8]. However, the synthesis of EC faces unique challenges, particularly the requirement of halogens as co-catalysts in the CO2 cycloaddition method. The existence of residual halogens in EC presents a potential hazard to the quality and safety of the resulting polyester and batteries. Therefore, it is crucial to employ innovative green techniques for producing halogen-free of EC [9,10]. MgO(100) surface is thermodynamically stable, which is beneficial for multiple cycles of EC generation [11]. Chowdhury et al. [12] have similarly observed the importance of catalyst stability in CO2 cycloaddition. They reported that MgO(200) remained the main exposed surface after five catalytic reactions in the presence of Bu4NBr, with the cyclic carbonate yield remaining almost unchanged. Our previous work suggested that MgO(100) surface loaded with lithium atom serves as a halogen-free alternative for activating epoxides, significantly reducing the activation energy required for EC generation compared to the MgO(100) surface. However, lithium-modified MgO(100) surface fail to achieve high EC selectivity below 643 K [13]. This highlights the need to develop novel MgO catalysts loaded with other metals to minimize by-product formation and sustain high EC yield under mild, halogen-free reaction conditions [14]. Metal atoms play a crucial role in many catalysts for generating cyclic carbonate. Modulating the catalytic activity of metal organic frameworks by using different metals as activating centers for CO2 cycloaddition leads to variations in both the rate-determining step (RDS) and the associated energy barriers. For example, Zn and Cu atoms as center metals both show low but distinct activation energy at the RDS for generating cyclic carbonate from propylene oxide (PO) and CO2. Specifically, when Cu is the center metal, the RSD is the ring-opening step, with an activation energy of 15.99 kcal⋅ mol−1. In contrast, when Zn is the center metal, the RDS is ring-closing step, with an activation energy of 14.62 kcal⋅ mol−1 [15]. These metals also exhibit excellent performance in other catalysts, such as ZnBr2–Ph4PI, Zn-organic framework, zinc-modified ZSM-5 zeolite, copper−organic framework assembled by Cu12 nanocages, often yielding 95−99% of cyclic carbonates [16–22]. Given these findings, substituting Cu and Zn atoms for Li atoms on the MgO(100) surface has the potential to further reduce the activation energy for EC generation and improve EC selectivity at temperatures below 674 K. Additionally, metals like Ag and Au, which share similar physical and chemical properties with Cu, may also be effective in promoting EC generation when loaded onto the MgO(100) surface. Furthermore, alkali and alkaline earth metals such as Na, K, Ca, Sr, and Ba have been shown to significantly activate CO₂ when loaded onto the MgO(100) surface, as demonstrated by Kim et al. [23]. This activation of CO2 could enhance EC selectivity under mild condition. Experimental research has also shown that Zn-M-Al-O composite oxide (where M=Ca, Sr, and Ba) can achieve over 97 % selectivity for propylene carbonate from PO and CO2 [24]. This indicates that Ca, Sr and Ba have the potential to replace the role of Li on the MgO(100) surface. Similarly, metals like Al have been shown important role in activating epoxides in mixed oxides to generate propylene carbonate [21]. Therefore, metals like Ga, In and Al can be added to the MgO(100) surface to investigate their effects on the cycloaddition of EO and CO2. This adjustment has the potential to enhance the selectivity of EC. In summary, Cu, Ag, Au, Zn, Na, K, Ca, Sr, Ba, Al, Ga, and In have the potential to be loaded onto the MgO(100) surface to vary the activation strengths of EO and CO2, thereby promoting EC selectivity under mild conditions. Altering the metal allows for the manipulation of the interactions between single metal atoms and the MgO(100) surface [25]. This modification serves as a method to induce a redistribution of the acid-base properties of catalysts, hence further varying the performance of catalysts for the EC formation. Interestingly, the yield of cyclic carbonate can be increased by reducing the total base site in mixed metal oxide [26]. Specifically, the yield of propylene carbonate (PC) rises from 63.1% to 90.6% as the base site decreases from 214 to 111 μmol⋅g −1. The effect of basicity on the selectivity of PC has also been studied by Fujita et al. [27], finding that the PC selectivity grows from 65.9% to 94.3% with the amount of intermediate-strength alkaline sites. Those phenomena indicate the existence of strong basic sites occupied by CO2, resulting in a decrease in the conversion of epoxides. However, the yield of cyclic carbonate can be decreased from 95% to 73% caused by the excessive formation of acidity in the application of ionic liquids and porous carbon for the CO2 cycloaddition [28]. Therefore, catalysts that are appropriate for CO2 cycloaddition necessitate a moderate acid-base center. Nevertheless, the alkalinity of MgO catalysts can be measured by CO2 temperature-programmed desorption (CO2-TPD), and CO2 adsorption energies exhibit the same trend as the basicity of the surfaces measured by CO2-TPD [26,29–32]. Those will enable the elucidation of the relationship between the acid-base of catalysts and their performance for CO2 cycloaddition. Steric and electronic effects also play an important role in the CO2 conversion. The yield of cyclic carbonates decreasing as the side groups of epoxides increase, which is 99% in propylene oxide (PO), 97% in 1,2-butylene oxide, and 91% in allyl glycidyl ether, respectively, when epoxides have electron-donating side groups [33]. However, the HCC(OMe) shows the lowest energy barriers for generating the five-membered metalacyclic complexes among six pathways in the coupling reactions of CO2 and alkynes mediated by Nickel(0) complexes, as the OMe substituent makes the alkyne more electron-rich, enhancing the nucleophilicity of the alkyne and lowering the coupling barrier [34]. Nevertheless, a lower energy barrier needed for opening the PO when the ligands change from 1,4-phthalaldehyde (BDA) to 2,5-di‑tert‑butyl‑1,4-benzoquinone (DTBBQ) because the single cobalt sites in DTBBQ-CMP nanosheets have a 13 % higher positive charge than that of BDA-CMP [35]. Therefore, investigating the steric and electronic effects on CO2 cycloaddition helps to explain why different catalysts or reactants have distinct reaction mechanisms. In this study, we employed density function theory (DFT) method to investigate the EC formation on the M-MgO(100) surfaces, where M stands for the loaded metal, including Cu, Ag, Au, Zn, Na, K, Ca, Sr, Ba, Al, Ga, and In. The changes in the adsorption of reactants and their C − O bond length adsorbed on the different catalysts, the Bader charge, the steric effect, as well as the molecular orbitals in transition states and reactants, will be analyzed to uncover the diverse reaction mechanisms for EC formation on the M-MgO(100) surfaces. Additionally, the effect of reaction conditions including temperature, pressure, and feeding sequence on the selectivity of EC will also be evaluated based on the microkinetic analysis. Consequently, a halogen-free, environmentally friendly, and durable M-MgO(100) catalyst that exhibits high EC selectivity at low temperatures will be achieved. 2 Computation details 2.1 Calculation methods The Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP 5.4.4) was employed to conduct density functional theory calculations [36,37]. The electronic calculations were performed using the Projector Augmented Wave (PAW) method, which provides a balance between computational efficiency and accuracy by combining the advantages of all-election methods and pseudopotentials [38]. To characterize the exchange correlation interaction, the generalized gradient approximation with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (GGA-PBE) function was chosen [39–41]. Accordingly, the PAW pseudopotential based on the PBE functional (PAW_PBE) was used in this work to ensure consistency between the exchange-correlation functional and the pseudopotentials [42]. The following electrons were considered explicitly: H(1 s), C(2 s, 2p), Mg(3 s), O(2 s, 2p), Cu(3d, 4 s), Ag(4d, 5 s), Au (5d, 6 s), Zn(3d, 4 s), Na(2p, 3 s), K(3 s, 3p, 4 s), Ca(3 s, 3p, 4 s) Sr(4 s, 4p, 4d, 5 s), Ba(5 s, 5p, 5d, 6 s), Al(3 s, 3p), Ga(3 s, 4p, 4p), In(4d, 5 s, 5p). The selected cutoff energy for this study was 400 electron volts (eV), and a K-point grid was employed using the Monkhorst-Pack method with dimensions of 2 × 3 × 1 [13]. The spin-polarization approach was used for all of the computations. In addition, the DFT-D3 approach along with the method of Grimme was used to consider the van der Waals contribution [43–45]. The atomic structures underwent relaxation using the conjugate gradient approach, which was implemented in the VASP code. This process continued until the election energy and forces on all unconstrained atoms became <1 × 10−5 eV and 0.03 eV⋅Å −1, respectively. Transition states were located by combining the climbing-image nudge elastic band method and dimer method [46,47]. The forces for all atoms in the optimized transition state structure using the dimer method were <0.05 eV [13,48]. The transition states were further confirmed by using vibrational frequency calculations. Bader charge analysis was conducted using the code created by Henkelman and co-workers [49,50]. Ab initio molecular dynamics (AIMD) simulations were carried out using the optimized structures to evaluate the dynamic stability of the M-MgO(100) with a time step of 1 fs for a total duration of 10 ps. The AIMD simulations were performed using NVT ensemble at a temperature of 298 K [51]. The other detailed calculation formulas can be seen in the Supplementary materials. 2.2 Surfaces models The information of cubic MgO unit cell with the lattice parameter of a = b = c = 4.210 Å is show in Fig. 1 . This lattice parameter differs from the experimentally reported value of 4.216 Å by only 0.14%, indicating that the calculation results in this work are reliable [52]. The pure MgO(100) and M-MgO(100) surfaces were modeled using a 2 × 3 supercell-slab of the (100) surface made up of four layers [53,54]. The top view and side view of MgO(100) surface are shown in Fig. 1. This surface was constructed from 48 O and 48 Mg atoms through the repetition Mg−O bonds. For the M-MgO(100) surface, single-atom metals were loaded. Additionally, the top two layers and species were allowed to relax, which represents the active surface, whereas the bottom two layers, representing the bulk, were fixed. The vacuum region was set at 20 Å to separate the slabs in a direction perpendicular to the surface. Furthermore, the most stable adsorption site for loaded metal atom on the M-MgO(100) surface is on the lattice oxygen of magnesium oxide, which is consistent with the previous work [13]. The side and top views of M-MgO(100) surfaces are shown in Fig. 1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 The stability of catalysts The binding energies between the loaded different metals and the MgO(100) surfaces are analyzed by Equation S1, and the results demonstrate that Cu, Ag, Au, Zn, Na, K, Ca, Sr, Al, Ga and In can be adsorbed stably on the MgO(100) surface with negative binding energies, as shown in Fig. S1. This indicates that the anchoring of these atoms on the MgO(100) surface is energetically favorable [55]. In addition, the M − O bond lengths between loaded metals and their bonded O atoms deliver an opposite trend to the binding energy (Fig. S1). Moreover, the Cu−O bond length of 1.968 Å, which corresponds to a binding energy of −123.1 kJ⋅mol−1, indicates Cu and the MgO(100) surface interact strongly. Similarly, Li atoms can stably adsorb on the MgO(100) surface via a Li−O bond with a binding energy of −108.9 kJ mol−1 [13]. Thus, the Cu-MgO(100) surface is stable. In addition, the strong interaction of loaded metal with the MgO(100) surface can be further understood from the charge density difference shown in Fig. S2, which is defined as the charge density of metal (M) adsorbed MgO(100) surface relative to that of the individual MgO(100) surface and M, as given in Equation S5. The results show that both charge accumulation (yellow color) and depletion (blue color) occur on the loaded metal and the MgO(100) surface. These correspond to electron donation from the M to the MgO(100) surface and back-donation from the MgO(100) surface to the loaded metal, respectively. Charge accumulation and depletion are mainly observed around the loaded metal, which contributes to its strong interaction with the MgO(100) surface. Similarly, when CO2 is adsorbed on the two-dimensional transition metal borides, it also exhibits charge donation and back-donation behavior. This indicates that CO2 interacts with the borides in a manner similar to the interaction between the loaded metal and the MgO(100) surface [56]. Thus, the negative binding energy indicates the loaded metal atoms are energetically favorable on the MgO(100) surface. Additionally, the differential charge density shows significant charge redistribution around the metal atoms, which further supports their stable adsorption. These results collectively suggest that the metal atoms are thermodynamically stable on the MgO(100) surface. Moreover, the AIMD results suggest M-MgO(100) surface can exist stably when the M presents the Cu, Cu, Ag, Au, Na, K, Ga, In, Ca, Sr and Al atoms, except for Zn atom, as shown in Figs. S3−13. Ba-MgO(100) surface was not be studied by using the AIMD because EC cannot be formed on this surface. Specifically, the Cu, Ag, Au, Na, K, Ga, In, Ca, Sr, and Al-MgO(100) surfaces are well preserved when the temperature rises to 298 K within 10 ps. The Zn-MgO(100) surface cannot be existed stably at 298 K because the Zn atom have moved away from the MgO(100) surface in this simulations process, as shown in Fig. S13. As a result, except for the Zn and Ba-MgO(100) surface, the other surfaces of M-MgO(100) surfaces existed stable in thermodynamics and kinetics [51,57]. 3.2 The reactant adsorption on the M-MgO(100) surface Loading Cu, Ag, Au, Zn, Na, K, Ca, Sr, Ba, Al, Ga and In onto the MgO(100) surface causes a noticeable change in the electron distribution on the M-MgO(100), which alters the reactant adsorption. The electron redistribution occurs primarily on the O atom and the loaded metal, as well as the Mg atom connected to the O atoms, as shown in Fig. S2. Moreover, EO adsorption is most stable at the top site of Mg1 on the M-MgO(100) surface, as shown in EO-1 in Figs. S14−S25. In this case, the adsorption of EO at the top of the Mg1 site on the M-MgO(100) surfaces is exothermic, generating negative adsorption energy. Also, the C − O bond length in the EO adsorbed on those catalysts exceeds its value in the gas phase of 1.442 Å, indicating that the EO is activated on these catalysts [13]. However, the most stable CO2 adsorption site on the M-MgO(100) surface occurs at the site of O1 top or the loaded metals, where the C atom of CO2 bonds with the O1 or loaded metals, as shown in CO2–1 in Figs. S14−S25. Moreover, CO2–2, a different form of CO2 that adsorbs in region B closest to EO-1, can react with EO-1, even though it has less adsorption energy than CO2–1, as shown in Figs. S14−S25. Obviously, the C − O bond lengths in CO2–1 and CO2–2 are greater than their values in the gas phase of 1.177 Å. Both of the CO2 adsorption states on the M-MgO(100) surfaces exhibit bent OCO angles compared to the gas phase. This shows that the CO2 is activated on these catalysts [13]. As a result, the area labeled as “blue-graffiti” (region A) exhibits significant electron transfer, which helps to strongly activate EO and CO2, shown in Fig. 2 . Additionally, region B (orange-graffiti) undergoes a restricted amount of electron transfer, where the reactants are mildly activated. Therefore, two adsorption forms to generate EC on the M-MgO(100) surfaces are considered: the first involves the co-adsorption of EO-1 and CO2–1 in region A, while the second entails the co-adsorption of EO-1 and CO2–2 in region A + B. However, only the co-adsorption of EO and CO2 in their most stable configurations is deemed capable of generating EC on the Al, Ca, Sr and Ba-MgO(100) surfaces, as CO2–2 cannot exist stably on these surfaces. The detailed path for generating EC on various M-MgO(100) surfaces will be discussed in the following section. 3.3 The reaction path Our previous investigation shows that CO2 cycloaddition can take place on the Li-MgO(100) surface in a number of pathways [13] . Similarly, on the M-MgO(100) surface, there are many potential routes to generate EC. The results show that there are five paths to generate EC on all MgO(100) surfaces modified with Cu, Ag, Au, Zn, Na, K, Ca, Sr, Ba, Al, Ga and In, as seen in Fig. 3 . Path 1 indicates the EC generation through a synergistic process without any intermediates. Path 2 and Path 5 denote the EC generation through a two-step route, with Path 2 proceeding via Int1 and Path 5 via Int2. Path 3 and Path 4 signify the EC generation through a three-step route, which includes the ring-opening reaction of EO to generate Int1, the insertion of CO2 to generate Int2 or Int3, and the ring-closing reaction. In the following sections, we will discuss the most energetically favorable paths for EC generation on each M-MgO(100) surface, which need the lowest activation energy at the rate-determining step (RDS) for generating EC. Furthermore, the alternative path to obtain EC via a higher energy barrier at the RDS than the optimal pathway is illustrated in the Figs. S26−S32. Also, evidence for both the concerted and partial concerted mechanisms for CO2 cycloaddition has been provided in Fig. S34. 3.3.1 EC generation via a one-step route When the loading metals are Cu, Ag, Au and Zn, EC is generated on the M-MgO(100) surface mainly via a one-step of Path 1, as illustrated in Figs. 4 a and 4b. Obviously, EC generation on the surface of these catalysts both starts with the same co-adsorption structures, in which EO and CO2 are co-adsorbed in region-A. Following the co-adsorption of EO and CO2 on the Cu-MgO(100) surface, the C3−Oc bond in EO is stretched from 1.461 to 1.774 Å, while the co-adsorbed CO2 undergoes deformation, resulting in the creation of Cu-TS1–1 transition state. And Cu-TS1–1 is followed by the formation of two new C − O bonds, after which EC formation occurs. The creation of EC on the Ag, Au and Zn-MgO(100) surfaces experiences analogous transition states. And the activation energies for the EC formation on the MgO(100) surface loaded with Cu, Ag, Au and Zn via the most energy-favorable pathways are 71.5, 82.2, 135.7 and 142.8 kJ⋅mol−1, respectively, as shown in Fig. 4b Furthermore, the concerted mechanism via a one-step path for CO2 cycloaddition with EO has also been observed on the faujasite zeolite (FAU), in which EC formation on the Cu-FAU catalyst has an activation barrier of 116.5 kJ⋅ mol−1 [58]. As a result, Cu-MgO(100) surface exhibits better activity to generate EC than the Cu-FAU due to its less activation energy in EC generation. Additionally, Fig. 4c shows the difference in the C − O bond between TS and initial reactants (d TS-R). The positive values of d TS-R indicate that the C − O bond length is greater in the TS than in the reactants, while the negative values present a shorter C − O bond in the TS than in the reactants. The results indicate that the formation of C1−Oc and C3−Ob bonds on the Cu and Ag-MgO(100) surfaces has distinctly asynchronous concerted characteristics. This phenomenon can be confirmed by the d TS-R between the C1−Oc and C3−Ob bonds in Figs. 4a and 4c. Obviously, the d TS-R of the C1−Oc bond in the Cu and Ag-TS1–1 is shortened by 0.145 and 0.015 Å, respectively, compared to the Cu and Ag-EOCO2. This makes it easier for the new C − O bonds to form. However, the d TS-R of the C3−Ob bond is elongated by 0.632 and 0.427 Å in the Cu and Ag-TS1–1, respectively, compared to the initial co-adsorption of EO and CO2, deviating from the direction of new C − O bond. As a result, the C1−Oc bond forms earlier than the C3−Ob, as shown in Figs. 4a and 4c. However, on the Au and Zn-MgO(100) surfaces, the d TS-R of the C3−Ob and C1−Oc bonds are both shorter in the TS than they were in the initial co-adsorption states. Furthermore, the variations of d TS-R in C1−Oc bonds are larger than in C3−Ob bonds, both on the Au and Zn-MgO(100) surfaces. In this case, the shortened values of C1−Oc bonds are 0.911 and 0.815 Å on the Au-MgO(100) and Zn-MgO(100) surfaces, respectively, as well as the shortened values of 0.208 and 0.063 Å for C3−Ob bonds on the Au and Zn-MgO(100) surfaces, respectively. Therefore, the extent of asynchronous concerted in TS on the Cu and Ag-MgO(100) surfaces exceeds that on the Au and Zn-MgO(100) surfaces. These differences could be attributed to the varying degrees of activation for EO and CO2 caused by different metals loaded onto the MgO(100) surface. Analogous to this, the difference in the degree of asymmetry usually occurs in the Diels-Alder reaction, in which the formation of two new C − C bonds happen at different times when the substituent of olefins is connected to different functional groups [59]. In addition, there are alternative methods to produce EC on these catalysts with a higher energy barrier at RDS than the aforementioned pathway, as can be found in Figs. S26 and S27. 3.3.2 EC generation through different intermediates In comparison to the above four catalysts, the adsorption energies of EO and CO2 on the Na and K-MgO(100) surfaces are both higher than those on the MgO(100) surfaces loaded with Cu, Ag, Au, and Zn. However, in order to develop tangible catalysts, it becomes imperative to study the relationship between the acid-base properties of the catalysts and the cycloaddition activity on the M-MgO(100) surfaces. 3.4 Analysis of micro properties of catalysts 3.4.1 The effect of localized acidity and alkalinity on the cycloaddition The adsorption energy of EO and CO2 can serve as an indicator of the level of reactant activation on the M-MgO(100) surface. This, in turn, has a significant impact on the activation energy at the RDS for the EC formation. Herein, the relationship between the adsorption energies of reactants and the activation energies at the RDS via the most favorable energy pathway for generating EC on the M-MgO(100) surface is analyzed. The adsorption energies of EO and CO2 on the most advantageous energy path, as well as their activation energies at the RDS, are drawn in the horizontal, vertical, and third coordinates in Fig. 9, respectively. Moreover, with the CO2 (NH3) adsorption energy can be used to describe the alkalinity (acidity) of metal oxides, it is possible to design catalysts precisely that exhibit excellent performance in EC generation with appropriate localized acidity and basicity [32]. Furthermore, the adsorption energies of EO and NH3 exhibit a comparable trend of variation on the M-MgO(100) surface, seen in Fig. 8 . Thus, the EO adsorption energy can be an appropriate substitute for the NH3 adsorption energy in evaluating acidity strength of the catalyst. Consequently, the deposition of various metals onto the MgO(100) surface will alter the spatial distribution of acidity and alkalinity, as well as influence the reaction pathway for generating EC and the catalytic activity in CO2 cycloaddition. Firstly, the reaction path for generating EC is significantly influenced by the acidity and alkalinity on the M-MgO(100) surfaces. It is observed that the M-MgO(100) surfaces can be classified into three categories based on their alkalinity strength. The first type, known as M 1-MgO(100) surfaces (M 1 = Cu, Ag, Au, and Zn), demonstrates lower alkalinity compared to the MgO(100) surface. The adsorption energies of CO2 on these surfaces are <60 kJ⋅mol−1. EC generation on the first type of catalyst occurs only through a one-step route, as shown in Figs. 4 and 9 . Furthermore, these surfaces exhibit enhanced acidity compared to the pure MgO(100) surface, a phenomenon ascribed to the elevated EO adsorption energies. Besides, the addition of the second metal to metal oxides has also been shown to successfully modulate the acid-base distribution on several mixed metal oxide catalysts [26,34]. Secondly, M 2-MgO(100) surfaces (M 2 = Na, K, Ga, and In) form the second type of moderately alkaline catalyst, exhibiting an alkalinity that ranges from 1 to 2 times that of the pure MgO(100) surface. The adsorption energies of CO2 on these surfaces range from 60 to 120 kJ⋅mol−1. Simultaneously, these surfaces exhibit greater acidity than the first catalysts. The production pathway of EC alters as the alkalinity and acidity increase. Currently, EC creation on these surfaces must follow a stepwise route containing Int2 or Int3, as illustrated in Figs. 5, 6 and 9. Increasing acidity is the primary component contributing to the stepwise route of generating EC. The rise in acidity facilitates the formation of stable intermediates via the ring-opening of the EO. The third type is the M 3-MgO(100) surface (M 3 = Ca, Al, and Sr), exhibiting over twice the alkalinity of MgO(100) surface. These catalysts exhibit strong alkalinity, with the CO2 adsorption energy above 120 kJ⋅mol−1. Obviously, these surfaces experience a further increase in alkalinity compared to the M 2-MgO(100) surface. Significant alkalinity is the primary factor that restricts EC generation to the stepwise route involving Int3, as the acidity of these catalysts has not increased to the same extent as their alkalinity. Therefore, the deposition of the metals onto the MgO(100) surface induces adjustments in the acid-base equilibrium, which subsequently result in various reaction paths in the cycloaddition process. The acidity and alkalinity on the M-MgO(100) surfaces also affect the activity of EC generation. The median activation energy for M 1-MgO(100), M 2-MgO(100) and M 3-MgO(100) surfaces is used to describe the average activation energy at RDS of generating EC. In general, there exists a correlation between the activation energies for the EC formation at the RDS and the adsorption energies of reactants, as shown in Fig. 9. This association suggests that the activation energies required for generating EC rise with increasing alkalinity of the M-MgO(100) surface. The average activation energies for the formation of EC under weak alkaline, medium alkaline and strong alkaline conditions are 109.0, 119.6 and 202.6 kJ⋅mol−1, respectively, shown in Fig. 9. These events have further clarified why adding more strong base sites does not improve the yield of cyclic carbonates in experiments [26,27]. Therefore, the weak alkaline condition is advantageous for CO2 cycloaddition. At the same time, a moderate acid is essential for the elevated activity of generating EC. This phenomenon has been seen on the Cu, Ag, Au and Zn-MgO(100) surfaces investigated in this study, as well as the Li-MgO(100) surface examined in previous investigations [13]. It is noteworthy that moderate acids combined with a slight base on the Cu-MgO(100) catalyst contribute to the cycloaddition of EO and CO2. Nevertheless, excessive acidity can diminish the selectivity of EC and output of cyclic carbonates, both in theoretical calculations and experiments [13,29]. Therefore, the adsorption energy of EO and CO2 can serve as a preliminary evaluation standard for the CO2 cycloaddition performance of the M-MgO catalysts. And the analysis of the acidity-basicity site on the catalysts is conducted to establish the association between the CO2 cycloaddition reaction and the varying strength of acid-base distribution on the M-MgO(100) surface. 3.4.2 The Bader charge, electrostatic potential, steric effects, density of states and reaction mechanism analysis The deposition of different metals onto the MgO(100) surface alters its acidity and alkalinity, mostly due to the charge redistribution of the catalyst surface. This phenomenon results in varying levels of charge acquired by EO and CO2 adsorbed on the different catalysts. As a result, various mechanism for the EC formation have been developed. The Bader charge, the bending angle of CO2, electrostatic potential (ESP), density of states (DOS) and molecular orbital (MO) were analyzed to conduct a more comprehensive analysis of the reaction mechanism for the EC formation on the MgO(100) surfaces loaded with different metals. The catalysts can be divided into three groups based on the reaction mechanism they conduct, and we selected one catalyst from each category for DOS investigation. The findings suggest that EO, CO2 and loaded metals present in the system mostly influenced the partial density of states (PDOS) near the Fermi level when the reactants co-adsorbed on the Cu, Na and Ca-MgO(100) surfaces (Figs. 11a and 11b). Also, the visualization of peaks close to the Fermi level is employed to identify their orbital contributions in CO2 cycloaddition. Following that, we will categorize catalysts and examine how these characteristics impact the EC generation. The first type is the weakly alkaline catalyst, characterized by the MgO(100) surface loaded with Cu, Ag, Au, and Zn. These catalysts show the same reaction mechanism for generating EC, as they all follow a one-step reaction pathway. The Bader charge of the O atom and the C atom of CO2 molecules in the gas phase are 1.01 and −2.02 |e|, respectively, as shown in Fig. 10a. Simultaneously, the ESP map indicates that O atoms in CO2 (or EO) exhibit a negative ESP, as is shown by the red, and are therefore prone to undergoing nucleophilic reactions. However, the C atom in CO2 (or EO) shows a positive electrostatic potential marked by blue, which will be an electrophilic site [34,61,62]. It is clear that CO2 and EO only got a small number of electrons from the first type of catalyst, with the total number of electrons on the M 1-MgO(100) surfaces being <0.50. This can be seen by looking at their Bader charge in the Δq-EO and CO2 when the reactants co-adsorb on the M 1-MgO(100) surface, as illustrated in the orange region in Figs. 10e and 10f. In this case, EC is generated via a concurrent occurrence of electrophilic and nucleophilic attack reactions between EO and CO2, in which the O atom of EO attacks the C atom of CO2 and the C atom of EO attacks the O atom of CO2, as shown in Fig. 10a. These are similar to the way that PO is activated by the HEMIMBr (1-(2-hydroxylethyl)-3-methylimidazolium bromide), in which the nucleophilic attack of the Br− activates the C atom of PO and the O atom is activated by the electrophilic attack of the H atom from the hydroxyl group [63]. In the case of CO2 co-adsorbed with EO on the Cu-MgO(100) surface, πu ∗(LUMO) orbitals of CO2 move towards the Fermi level compared to the CO2 in the gas phase because some electrons transfer from Cu-MgO(100) to CO2 and are filled into the anti-bonding orbitals of CO2. These findings align with the Bader charge analysis in Fig. 10f and the DOS analysis in Fig. 11a. By visualizing the orbitals for the wave function in close proximity to the Fermi level, we can definitively ascertain that EO mainly contributes to the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO), while CO2 primarily contributes to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) throughout the cycloaddition reaction process, as shown in Figs. 11a and 11b. Similarly, CO2 participates in the cycloaddition reaction through the LUMO orbitals on the Ag, Au and Zn-MgO(100) surfaces, as the number of electrons obtained by CO2 on these surfaces is <0.50, as depicted in Fig. 10f. To get a better look at the molecular orbital details involved in the reaction, we took the MgO(100) substrate away from the whole Cu-TS1–1 structure. This is reasonable, as the contributions of peaks near the Fermi level mainly come from Cu, EO and CO2. Obviously, the height-matched wave function phase between the HOMO orbital of EO in the Cu-TS-HOMO and the LUMO orbital of CO2 in Cu-TS-LUMO, along with the two pairs of overlapping geometric shapes, promotes the formation of C − O bonds between EO and CO2 (Fig. 11b). In addition, as electrons are transferred from catalysts to the LUMO of CO2, the CO2 molecules have a tendency to undergo bending to maintain thermodynamic stability. The Walsh diagram of CO2 orbitals in Fig. 10 g gives the correlation between the OCO angle and orbital energies [64,65]. Generally, the low number of electrons obtained by EO and CO2 results in a slight polarization of the reactants, thereby promoting the production of EC through a concerted mechanism [66]. And the energy barriers for generating EC are mainly determined by the number of electrons obtained by EO on the Cu, Ag and Au-MgO(100) surfaces. In this case, the Cu-MgO(100) surface needs the lowest energy barrier for EC generation compared to Ag and Au -MgO(100) surfaces due to the highest number of obtained electrons, with a value of 71.5 kJ⋅mol−1. The reaction mechanism reverses on the M-MgO(100) surfaces when their alkalinity and acidity exceed those on the pure MgO(100) surface. Specifically, EC generation follows a stepwise pathway on the M 2,3-MgO(100) surfaces, whereas it follows a synergistic pathway on the M 1-MgO(100) surfaces. This difference is attributed to the total number of electrons obtained by EO and CO2 during co-adsorption, which exceeds 0.50 |e| on the M 2,3-MgO(100) surfaces but is <0.50 |e| on the M 1-MgO(100) surfaces. However, the strength and type of alkalinity significantly influence the reversal of the reaction mechanism. The disparity in the number of electrons acquired by CO2 is the crucial factor that differentiates the alkalinity on the M 2,3-MgO(100) surfaces. When the number of electrons acquired by CO2 is <0.50, the orbital contribution of the reactants remains essentially unchanged. This is evident on the Na (or K)-MgO(100) surface, where EO provides the HOMO orbital and CO2 provides the LUMO orbital in the CO2 cycloaddition, as shown in Figs. 10 e, 10f, 11a and 11b. When the number of electrons acquired by CO2 exceed 0.50 on the M-MgO(100) surface, the role of orbital of the reactants changes. These changes occur on the Ga, In, Al, Ca and Sr-MgO(100) surfaces. This phenomenon leads to CO2 providing for the HOMO orbital in the CO2 cycloaddition, while the EO donates to the LUMO orbital on the Ca-MgO(100) surface, as shown in Figs. 10f, 11a and 11b. Subsequently, the σ orbitals of C − O bond in Int1 and πu ∗ orbitals of CO2 matching on the side to form a Ca-Int3, as illustrated in Figs. 11 a and 11b. The inversion of the orbital role of CO2 is attributable to large number of electrons acquisition by the anti-bonding orbital of CO2 from the Ca-MgO(100) surface, leading to the πu ∗ orbitals of CO2 migrating below the Fermi level. In addition, the variation in the Bader charge of the C1 atom in CO2 (Δq-C1) adsorbed on the M-MgO(100) surface is the primary factor contributing to the disparate distribution of total electrons in CO2, as shown in Figs. 10b and 10c. Furthermore, the electrons in the C1 atom of CO2 determines the order of the new C − O bond formation. As a result, EC formation on the Na, K-MgO(100) surface is via the stepwise route containing Int2, while the EC formation on the Ga, In, Al, Ca and Sr-MgO(100) surfaces is through the stepwise route containing Int3. This is because the C1 atom of CO2 on the Na, K-MgO(100) surface lost electrons at 0.06 and 0.05 |e|, respectively. This change in electrons significantly lowers the charge density around the C1 atom, making an enhancement of positive ESP at the C1 atom. This can be evidenced in the deeper blue ESP in the C atom of CO2 on the Na-MgO(100) surface than that on the Cu-MgO(100) surface in Fig. 10a. Hence, the electrophilic attack reaction, wherein the C1 atom of CO2 reacts with the Oc atom of Int1 to generate Int2, is more favorable compared to the nucleophilic attack process involved the Ob atom of CO2 and the C3 atom of Int1 to produce Int3. Consequently, EC generates more easily via Int2 than Int3 on the Na (or K)-MgO(100) surfaces. And the energy barriers for generating Int2 via the bonding of C1−Oc are 65.5 and 69.5 kJ⋅mol−1 (Fig. 5b), while formatting the Int3 via the formation of C3−Ob are 122.8 and 156.5 kJ⋅mol−1 (Figs. S29 and S30) on the Na and K-MgO(100) surfaces, respectively. In contrast, the electrons obtained by C1 atoms of CO2 are 1.07, 1.04, 0.61, 0.54 and 0.53 |e| on the Sr, Ca, Al, Ga and In-MgO(100) surfaces, respectively. Therefore, the ESP of the C atom in CO2 is red and chartreuse on the Ca and Ga-MgO(100), respectively, as shown in Figs.10a and 10b. Simultaneously, these events cause the OCO angle of CO2 to greatly bend to preserve its thermodynamic stability. The bending angle increases as the number of electrons obtained by CO2 decreases, as shown in Figs. 10d and 10f. Consequently, the diminished electrophilic capacity in the C1(CO2) atoms and the significant steric hindrance caused by the bending of CO2 pose disadvantages for the bonding of the C1−Oc bond in Int2 via the C1 atom of CO2 attacking the Oc atom of Int1. As a result, EC generates on the Ca, Sr, Al, Ga and In-MgO(100) surfaces mainly through the stepwise routes containing Int3. Therefore, the electron transfer and OaC1Oc angle in CO2 at the co-adsorption state can serve as indicators for predicting the general course of the CO2 cycloaddition process. Thus, as the electrons obtained by the C(CO2) atom increases and the bending angle of CO2 decrease, the activation energy required for generating EC via Int3 gradually decreases on the Ga, In, Al, Ca and Sr-MgO(100) surfaces. Similarly, the steric hindrance effect hindering CO2 conversion has also been observed in the coupling of alkynes and CO2, in which the yield of cyclic carbonates falls as the size of the side groups of epoxides increases [33]. Hence, the interactions between loaded metals and MgO lead to electron transfer, facilitating the activation of reactants and lowering the activation energy required for EC production compared to the pure MgO(100) surface. This demonstrates the potential for supported metal to replace halogen on the MgO(100) surface [13,67,68]. Furthermore, the activation types EO and CO2 on the Cu-MgO(100) surface are different from those on the halogen-containing catalysts. The halogen often acts as a nucleophile to attack the C atom of EO, accompanied by the electrophilic effect of metals on the O atom of EO, promoting the ring opening of EO [15]. In our work, the C − O bond in EO is polarized by electron transfer between the Cu-MgO(100) surface and EO. At the same time, CO2 is activated on the Cu-MgO(100) surface after obtaining electrons from it. As a result, the HOMO orbital of EO and the LUMO orbital of CO2 are highly symmetrical and phase-matched, reducing the activation energy required to generate EC. Besides, the reversal of the mechanism of the CO2 cycloaddition reaction is mainly manifested in three aspects: the reaction pathway for EC generation, the sequences of the new C − O bond creation in the reaction route and the role of orbitals contributions in reactants. The Bader charge of the C atom in CO2 plays an important role in reversing the reaction mechanism. Thus, the electron transfer between M-MgO(100) and CO2 significantly influences the electrophilic-nucleophilic strengths of reactants, the order of new C − O bond formation between EO and CO2, the steric hindrance, the reaction mechanism, and the orbital contributions involved in the CO2 cycloaddition process on the M-MgO(100) surfaces. Similarly, the electron transfer in CO2 also determines its hydrogenation ability. The fewer electrons obtained by the O atom in CO2 make it less susceptible to electrophilic attack, including protonation to COOH* [69]. Consequently, these investigations would promote the understanding of the bonding process between the O(C) atom of CO2 and the C(O) atom of EO. 3.5 Microkinetic analysis of EC generation on the Cu-MgO(100) surface The previous section has provided insights into the influence of the local acid-base properties, charge transfer, and steric hindrance on the EC formation on the M-MgO(100) surfaces. The conclusions are shown as follows: Ethylene oxide (EO) and CO2 are activated by the acidic and alkaline sites on the M-MgO(100) surface, respectively. MgO(100) surfaces modified by Cu, Ag, Au, and Zn exhibit weaker alkalinity compared to the pure MgO(100) surface. On these surfaces, EC generation follows a synergistic route, with the total number of electrons obtained by EO and CO₂ fewer than 0.50 |e| . In contrast, loading Na, K, Ca, Sr, Ba, Al, Ga and In onto MgO(100) surfaces increases both alkalinity and acidity, leading to a mechanism reversal and a stepwise pathway for generate EC, with the total number of electrons obtained by EO and CO₂ exceeding 0.50 |e|. The electron transfer between the loaded metal and MgO facilitates the activation of EO and CO2, thereby substituting the electron-donating influence of halogens. When CO2 acquires >0.50 |e|, it results in a reversal of the reaction mechanism, as demonstrated by alterations to the sequence of new C − O bond formation, and the role of the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of CO2 in the CO2 cycloadditions process. The diminished electrophilicity of C atoms in CO2 and the significant steric hindrance created by the OCO angle in CO2 often elevate the energy barrier for generating EC due to the high charges present in CO2. Cu-MgO(100) performs well in the CO2 cycloaddition and displays a higher EC selectivity than Li-MgO(100). The HOMO orbital of EO and the LUMO orbital of CO2 are highly symmetrical and phase-matched due to the appropriate amount of electrons obtained by EO and CO2 from the Cu-MgO(100) surface, thereby reducing the activation energy required to generate EC. At 298 K and 1 atm, it has a 98% selectivity of EC. These are attributed to the weaker acidity of the Cu-MgO(100) surface compared to the Li-MgO(100) surface. Furthermore, these findings will aid in lowering energy consumption. coredata.dc:description: The CO2 cycloaddition with ethylene oxide (EO) to generate ethylene carbonate (EC) is a green method for converting exhaust gas into fine chemicals. However, pure MgO exhibits low EC yield under halogen-free and mild reaction conditions. This study explores EC generation on single-atom catalysts of MgO(100) surfaces loaded with Cu, Ag, Au, Zn, Na, K, Ca, Sr, Ba, Al, Ga and In through density functional theory (DFT) calculation. The results show that the mechanism reversal observed in the reaction pathway for EC generation and the role of CO₂ are attributed to changes in the electrons number obtained by EO and CO₂ co-adsorbed on the MgO(100) surfaces loaded with metals. For EC generation, surfaces loaded with Cu, Ag, Au, and Zn show a synergistic route where EO and CO₂ obtained fewer than 0.50 |e|. However, other surfaces have a stepwise pathway when this number exceeds 0.50. The participation of CO₂'s frontier orbitals in the reaction depends on the electrons obtained from the catalyst. On the Cu, Ag, Au, Zn, Na, and K-MgO(100) surfaces, CO₂ obtains fewer than 0.50 |e| and contributes LUMO orbitals, whereas on other surfaces, it obtains >0.50 |e| and contributes HOMO orbitals. Notably, the Cu-MgO(100) surface exhibits over 98 % EC selectivity at 1 atm and 298 K due to its weak alkalinity. It provides an ideal microenvironment that activates EO and CO2, replacing the role of halogens and offering a novel catalyst to significantly boost EC yield under halogen-free and mild reaction conditions.
